title: Buenos Aires to Uruguay Coast Loop (15 days, Culture + Beaches)

overview.why_this_route: Short ferry crossings make Uruguay extremely easy to reach, with minimal travel fatigue and flexible return options. Distances are small, transport is frequent, and August–September offers cooler, comfortable weather for cities and coastal areas.

key_highlights.Montevideo: relaxed capital culture, markets, coastal rambla
key_highlights.Punta del Este: classic beach resort with budget-friendly hostels off-season
key_highlights.Cabo Polonio: remote beach village with rustic accommodation and strong backpacker vibe

day_by_day: Days 1–4: Buenos Aires — Stay days exploring the city
Day 5: Buenos Aires → Colonia del Sacramento — Travel day (ferry)
Days 6–7: Colonia del Sacramento — Stay days
Day 11: Montevideo → Punta del Este — Travel day (bus)
Days 12–13: Punta del Este — Stay days (beaches)
Day 14: Punta del Este → Cabo Polonio — Travel day (bus + park transfer)
Day 15: Cabo Polonio → Montevideo — Travel day
Day 16: Montevideo → Buenos Aires — Travel day (ferry)
Day 17: Buenos Aires — Final buffer / departure day

modifications.shorter_version: Remove Cabo Polonio and add one extra night in Punta del Este before returning to Montevideo.
modifications.longer_version: Add two extra days in Buenos Aires or Montevideo for deeper cultural exploration.
modifications.alternative_branch: Replace Punta del Este with Piriápolis for a quieter, more low-key beach town with fewer crowds and cheaper accommodation.
